Description: Sherd of East Dorian Late Wild Goat Style pottery plate; white slip; interior: two black bands at junction of floor and rim; on floor part of goat (snout and forehead remaining) to left; pinwheel rosette, maeander, and cross as filling ornament; exterior reserved with two pairs of wheel-cut grooves.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to Dupont and Thomas (2006, p. 80), analysis of the fabric does not provide a precise region in eastern Greece from which the vase originated but Dupont and Thomas discard both a Rhodian and Nile Delta production. They suggest that the sherd probably has a East Dorian provenance. Kos is the probable origin in the light of the analyses published by Villing and Mommsen, BSA 112 (2017) 99-154, esp. 112-3. Sample number 'NAU 53' (Dupont and Thomas 2006, 78-9).
Bibliographic references: Dupont & Thomas 2006 / Naukratis: Les Importations Grecques Orientales Archaïques (p. 78-80, 82-84, fig. 4) (Nau 53)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GM.01)
